SENT.plain: A 55-year-old woman presented with moyamoya disease manifesting as recurrent transient ischemic attacks despite taking aspirin and antihypertensive agent
Angiography showed the characteristic angiographic appearance with bilateral internal carotid artery occlusion and abnormal collateral vessels
Left external carotid angiography demonstrated moderate stenosis of the proximal external carotid artery (ECA)
A self-expandable stent was successfully placed in the left ECA to improve ipsilateral cerebral perfusion
The patient had an uneventful outcome after a 1-year follow up
Involvement of the proximal ECA is very unusual in moyamoya disease, and might result from hemodynamic stress or degenerative atherosclerosis
Revascularization procedures for stenoses of proximal ECA may improve cerebral perfusion in patients with moyamoya disease
